messages.content: I will collate the governance related stuff. Have asked for a governance channel as it goes beyond legal structure.

So specifically on legal structure.
Med/Long term I think my proposal would be:

Delaware LLC as the investment vehicle.
Unincorporated association as the DAO vehicle.
Have the UA as a member (legal term) of the LLC along with 2-5 other members voted in by the DAO.
UA performs deal flow, risk and creates binding instructions on the legal member via votes or staking. The member is then obligated to take action on those instructions within the LLC.

This way we decentralise the DAO, the decisionmaking and the deal flow. The LLC stands as the investment vehicle so fast moving advantage. Over time work out how to move away from the LLC model.

Agreed! This is extremely similar to what we recommend at Syndicate. We have template legal docs ready for this use case: https://syndicatedao.gitbook.io/syndicate-wiki/web3-investment-clubs/create-a-legal-entity/template-legal-docs

Have been talking to a lot of corporate lawyers on this front re: setting up funds that are DAO-like/community governed, consensus right now is that due to lack of precedent or regulatory clarity, might need a 2-step process to get off ground, starting w/ a Series LLC structure as the longer-term aspects are ironed out

As far as state/jurisdiction selection, DE, NV, possibly WY, but there's a lot of debate about whether seeking a 501c3 status for the final form entity might bring a lot of tax benefit (which would then need to be a c-corp), so that's another angle to consider for the long term (e.g. requirements for Series LLC conversion to C Corp)

There are also two parallel legal/regulatory tracks that have to be considered: (1) The structure of "fund" or DAO entity itself and (2) legal treatment of the governance token/digital asset, the comments above are on (1) not (2)

Save, have been working through this for another major project. We are likely settling on CA PBC with the UA as the member. Allows us to thread the needle. Would work with a Delaware LLC as a for profit also though as far as I am aware.

So a few ways this could work.

Simple TradFi - Hyperscale acts [like] a fund and gives out USD 200k for 5% of a project/venture…. We all understand this model.

Token based - Hyperscale holds $10m in reserve, gives out 100 tokens to each project in return for 5% of a project/venture. Crucially Hyperscale also promises to purchase each token for $2k, selling the token back to Hyperscale draws down the reserve and funds the projects… but the tokens can also be bought/sold/hodl by anyone. Maybe even listed somewhere? Pending legality.

If one project succeeds the value of that project rises, the value of the 5% Hyperscale stake rises and the value of all tokens rises too. Every project benefits from the success of any single project as their stack of 100 tokens rises in value as it represent 5% ownership of all projects and is backstopped with the $10m fund to be drawn down.

Investing then becomes self policing as each project only wants other successes projects in their Hyperscale round.
It creates a virtuous circle, where projects are motivated to share resources and help each other succeed. If another project succeeds it increase the value of the tokens and increases the notional funding for all projects with the same token.

For startups looking to provide tokens as shares of the organization (obviously securities?) as compensation for labor and to retail investors, what's the best route to take to do this legally and with limited liability?

Lots of ways to explore, but the idea is that the token confers 2 things.
1). the right to redeem for cash.
2). If not redeemed the token represents a share of the equity of all the projects held by Hyperscale
If the token is not redeemed it acts like a share certificate in the community
So in theory the value of the token could rise above USD 2000, if some of the projects are successful
This then increases the available funding for the other projects automatically
And encourages everyone in the community to help each other and to collaborate

Well it has a floor price which is the value for which it can be redeemed
So $10m into a fund, less $1m for admin is $9m invested. That’s $200k for 45 projects. If each project gets 100 tokens on approval into the community then the face value of each token is $2000
If one of the projects takes off , the yet to be redeemed tokens will be worth more than $2000 as they represent equity in that project

messages.content: Setting this up to be a fully decentralized structure should not come at the cost of taking responsibility or developing trust with users—especially new users. Developing a compelling project that provides value to people should be the primary goal. In terms of the legal structure, it seems most effective to have Sam own and invest in the initial operation and then transition to the democratized version once we have a robust platform and secure way to ensure the transition occurs smoothly. If some people are concerned with Sam running away with the equity, then just have him agree to a legal statement that he will transition the platform to the democratized version in the future. I believe the legal structure and operational procedures should merely be a compliment to the larger goal of developing this to be robust on a technical level and trustworthy on a social level. I have experience with wealth management and securities law but that will be useless if this is built in a way that brings us into hot water. Very excited to see where this all goes, I’ve never seen a project get launched and grow this quickly.

Basical legal structure agreed:
**Investment Side (Hyperscale Fund)**
Sam acting as investment vehicle personally. May choose to invest via an LLC but in a personal capacity.

**DAO Side (Hyperscale DAO)**
DAO can either remain as a Discord-based community that guides Sam or can take steps to form for committed members as an unincorporated association.  This can happen over the course of v0.1 running with a view to having it complete in time for 1.0

-For MVP on legal structure needed steps are guidance from Sam and his legal team on exact structure and if any formal processes are needed from us to meet his legal risk and process.

A month ago I devised a potentially novel concept to that could serve as a potential loop hole to get around investor accreditation issues....

If you follow the NFT space, you might remember last month a crypto punk was sold for over $500M.  The person who owned the punk used a flash loan to buy and repay the loan over the course of a single transaction. Which now shows the punk sold for over $500M.... https://www.coindesk.com/tech/2021/10/29/heres-why-a-cryptopunk-sold-for-530m/

Which got me thinking...

So what if a project issued NFTs to DAO members, used a flash loan to purchase the NFT for $5M each and set a lockup on the NFT. Now every member holding any NFT of such, should be able to qualify as a Qualified Purchaser as they hold asset(s) of $5M or more in value, which eliminates the 99 investor problem investor syndicates often run into. More info here -> https://feld.com/archives/2014/01/99-investor-problem.html

To avoid potential unwanted tax exposure the NFT holder could burn the NFT by year end and re-issue a new one at the start of the next year, this way any potential gains are offset.

Delaware law allows both corporations and LLCs to keep “records” on blockchain.  

When merging the idea of a DAO with a C-Corp, the first step is considering the corporate structure: Shareholders, Directors, and Officers.   

Shareholders are the owners and they elect the Directors. Directors can have various powers but their main function is electing the Officers.  Officers are in day to day control of the corporation subject to powers/limitations defined by the articles/by-laws sometimes subject to vote by the Board.  

It may help to consider a C-Corp to automatically have multiple DAOs built-in, say a DAO for shareholders/BOD respectively.  I think this concept can be merged with ENS domains and subdomains, with each subdomain wrapped into its own token as desired, for example:

-corp.eth (the DE C-Corp)
-shareholders.corp.eth (shareholder dao)
-directors.corp.eth (BOD dao)

Selling tokens for the shareholders.corp.eth DAO would almost inevitably run into securities issues unless structured to fit an exception to registration. One idea to circumvent this could  be an airdrop of shareholder.corp.eth tokens. 

Directors.corp.eth DAO tokens that are limited to governance/voting rights are very likely the easiest to sell while minimizing any risk of securities issues.  Unlike a traditional C-Corp where shareholders elect directors, the directors could be unelected and include all that hold a directors.corp.eth DAO token. The idea of a Directors DAO electing Officers that generally have day to day control of corp.eth subject to Director control/votes over budget is very likely the most effective, especially in these early days of DAO operations.

People might push back against the “boomerness” of this type of structure and prefer an LLC over C-Corp where instead of 3 levels to the organization there are 2: members(owners)/managers.  More practically the LLC also has less compliance formalities.

Ill pro-offer the following examples that serve as potential domestic models (non-DAOs) consistent with the paper and an existing off-shore DAO model:

1.  The Green Bay Packers, Inc., a Wisconsin Non-profit Stock Company.  The only not for profit NFL team, every 10 years or so they raise funds by publicly issuing “stock” to fund the team operations.  Every public offering they obtain a no-action letter from the SEC so there is an existing legal framework, just replace their “stock” with  governance tokens.

2.  Erica Enders Racing, LLC, a Texas LLC.  Very similar to Green Bay Packers, except a for profit LLC, the Enders race team raises funds through a public offering of  LLC Membership. Similarly the team obtains no-action letters from the SEC so again there is legal precedent.

3. The ENS Foundation, a Caymen Islands Exempted Limited Guarantee Foundation Company (“non-profit”).  Uniquely structured compared to GB Packers where the DAO is essentially a made up council within the Foundation, often called committees within US entities. Perhaps the most interesting/beneficial from the tax perspective.

The respective Articles are all available, as well as the SEC no-action letter requests/SEC responses. If anyone would like to take a deep dive I can provide links to the same.

These securities laws generally make it illegal to sell loans
or shares to members in a broad offering, even to a community or members of a co-op, unless state or federal securities registration is filed (which
is usually much too expensive and detailed to be practical) or there is an
exemption from this registration requirement.
Consequently, exemption from securities registration for co-op member loans and preferred shares is key. Most of the co-op member investment programs use a combination of the SEC “intrastate exemption” and
a state-specific exemption for securities sold to cooperative members. The
intrastate exemption precludes SEC jurisdiction if the program is limited
to residents of a single state (there cannot be even one non-resident member investor) and the co-op is doing business in the state. The SEC rules say that: (i) the co-op must have derived 80 percent of its gross revenues
from within the state in the past six months; (ii) 80 percent of the co-op’s
assets must be located in the state; (iii) 80 percent of the proceeds of the
offering must be used within the state; and (iv) the principal office of the
co-op must be located in the state

I’m interpreting this statement to mean that each of the smaller entities would invest in a particular niche. I’d expect that to be a concern from a diversification perspective. Investors need exposure to a portfolio of these bets to try and increase the probability that they have exposure to the rare outlier returns. To answer a few questions -
I agree that the log distribution of $HV AND quadratic voting is probably too much.
Best allocators get voting power, as long as $HV is awarded on merit as well.
Multivoting without QV is an interesting idea, I agree that with a log limit it gives the properties you're describing.

Per $HV awarded per round, no carryover - each "round" of DAO race or voting should provide $HYPE holders a set amount of $HV _for that round only_ - you can't bank $HV round to round. This pushes allocators/voters into the pool.

This is reasonably what I was going to try and capture with double OHM.  We have two ways of "protocol owned value" - one is people buying into $HYPE with outside assets, ala OHM.  The other is $HYPE being converted into protocol tokens that go into the treasury. Built correctly, as you started to describe, the protocol tokens ALSO result in more $HYPE.

Rage quitting is an interesting twist - allowing people to exit with a tax is probably ok.
One challenge: without proof of ID, the use of a log over wallet value for $HV means it is better to run hundreds of wallets and delegate your votes to a single master wallet.

I like the idea of trying to leverage a market mechanism to facilitate discovery of strong capital allocators. I’m wondering whether the people that look like the best capital allocators in the short run turn out to be the best capital allocators in the long run. For example, Bob casts the first vote in the entity that wins the DAO race 5 out of 10 weeks in a row. Alice casts the first vote in the entity that wins the DAO race 1 out of 10 weeks in a row. But, because of the power law distribution of winners here, Alice’s pick ends up being worth far more than all 5 of Bob’s combined. The problem is that, for many people, Bob will appear to be the better capital allocator until years later when it becomes clear that Alice’s pick was the giant winner in the bunch.

And, this gets even messier when you consider that the best early stage capital allocators often (i) are independent thinkers, (ii) make picks that often look like bad ideas initially, (iii) make non-obvious picks because they understand something others don't, and (iv) have skin in the game.

Option #5: Combinations

So far, the most common approach I’ve seen is actually to mix and match. Typically this means creating a Foundation that is the official legal wrapper of the “DAO” and a separate, wholly unrelated, “Development Agency” (DA) onshore somewhere. This DA is incorporated as an LLC or local equivalent and is registered as a normal non-crypto entity.

A common path is the Cayman Foundation + a Singapore entity. Singapore is often chosen because of it’s relatively low tax rate (~17%), business-friendly regulation, and ease of set up for non-Singaporean residents.

Here’s how it works: the DAO has the treasury. Typically, the treasury is held in a multi-sig wallet that “belongs” to the DAO. The DAO/Foundation should also have a business account with an exchange like FTX to provide a fiat off-ramp should you need to pay lawyers, accountants, etc in meatspace.

The DA pays the leadership team and all associated expenses for the DAO. The Foundation has a Service agreement with the DA and pays accordingly. If, for example, there were $100,000 in expenses, the Foundation may send $120,000 to the DA. The DA then pays taxes on the $20k of profit, ensuring that you are paying taxes somewhere as mentioned at the beginning of this essay. In this fashion, the dual structure seems to provide the ideal balance of Legal Liability and Tax Protection.
